Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research activities that will be undertaken in this project are:(1) the development of theoretically-based, microgenetic learning analytic protocols aimed at understanding middle school student learning in a robotics setting as well as the development of theoretically-based, sentiment analysis protocols aimed at understanding the salience of stereotype threat for underrepresented students studying in a robotics context; (2) pilot testing these protocols on an existing data set; (3) refining and improving the protocols based on the results of the pilot test; and (4) conducting original research on the development of computational thinking in underrepresented middle school students studying in a robotics context, including examining the salience of stereotype threat on student activity.

Microgenetic analysis refers to the study of learning changes where:

1. Observations span the period of rapidly changing competency
2. Within the this period the density of observations is high relative to the rate of change
3. Observations are analyzed intensively

This proposal combines microgenetic analysis with computer science based learning analytics. The computer science based learning analytics take computer captured data and analyzes and mines that data for understanding of student learning. It is frequently used in intelligent tutoring systems and Massive Open Online Courses. In such cases, every keystroke is captured and the learning analytics is about making sense of those captured keystrokes.

The goal of this FIRE proposal is to increase the diversity of individuals who enter the field of computing by engaging in research on the development of computational thinking in underrepresented middle school students as they interact in a robotics environment. This research will include an examination of the salience of stereotype threat in an all girl robotics study setting. The PIs will achieve this project goal through the creation of a new research method that combines microgenetic analysis techniques derived from the field of developmental psychology with learning analytic techniques, derived from the field of computer science. The PIs term this new method Microgenetic Learning Analytics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported “Microgenetic Learning Analytics” DRL – #1253250, focuses on three areas in the field of computer science and computer science education. First, it explored the use of computational methods for supporting research on human learning. Recent advancements in natural language processing have made it feasible to use computational methods to classify and categorize spoken conversations in such a way as to identify important learning processes that unfold in collaborative learning settings. The second area of research undertaken concerns girls’ development of specific thinking processes that are typical of computer scientists, these thinking processes are collectively referred to as computational thinking. The third area of research examined girls’ feelings about their own ability to perform in a highly technological environment, in this case, a robotics learning environment.

The significance of our research relates to both the field of computer science and to computer science education. In terms of our first area, our work in natural language processing revolved around the development of an interdisciplinary method of segmentation and annotation of the data using an automated parts of speech tagging utility, coupled with our computational thinking coding scheme. This exploratory work helped us to develop a meaningful visualization of our dataset and to identify important learning processes students were engaged with as they worked in the robotics environment. We are now partnering with a computer science researcher with expertise in computational linguistics to further this work towards the development of a more fully automated process of data analysis. Developing the ability to automate the analysis of everyday, spoken conversations is a big challenge in the field of computer science, success with this automation will have far reaching implications in a number of research, commercial, and civic arenas.

The significance of our second and third research areas relate to computer science education, and, specifically, to gender equity in computer science. Computing and computer science are important aspects of the working world today. Indeed, computer and mathematics occupations in the US are projected to be the fourth fastest growing professions between 2014-2024, with estimated growth of 13.1 percent (or 531,400 new jobs) (US Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), 2015). However, while computer science is an important occupation with many job opportunities, few women are entering the field of computer science in college or as a career. Vocational decisions are most likely to be made in later adolescence, yet these decisions are affected by factors encountered in one’s earlier life including exposure, access, and experience in specific fields. Research indicates that self-efficacy for a particular field is a key factor in selecting a career in that area, and self-efficacy is most greatly affected by personal accomplishments in the specific field.  However, due to societal bias, girls and women have less exposure, access, and experience with important areas of learning, such as computer science. Therefore, their entrance into these fields is hindered.  Providing girls with opportunities to achieve personal accomplishments in the area of computer science, then, is an important means of supporting their entrance into the field. Moreover, developing a clear understanding of how girls learn in computer science based learning environments, such as robotics, is a key aspect of creating meaningful opportunities for them. This grant project has produced such knowledge.

Our research results in areas two and three are as follows: (1) girls’ computational thinking skills develop while working with robotics, specifically, they develop the ability to move from concrete to abstract problem solving strategies that take into account variables that affect the overall performance of the robotic device; (2) girls who engaged in discussions focused on algorithmic development at both the operational and variable levels were more likely to attempt more challenging robotics tasks, indicating greater confidence and higher levels of learning in the environment; (3) role assumption in the robotics environment hindered collaboration, except during challenge trials; (4) girls’ were equally likely as boys to attribute difficulty with robotics tasks to external, as opposed to internal loci. These findings support the following recommendations for the development of robotics learning environments: (1) robotics teaching should include discussion of both concrete and abstract approaches to problem solving; (2) robotics instruction should emphasize and support student discussions of various algorithmic approaches to problem solving – specific scaffolds can be developed to aid in these high level discussions, for example documentation and note-taking related to algorithmic development; (3) teachers should support role rotation through role assignment at the challenge level, thereby affording each child an opportunity to engage with each role on the robotics team; (4) when possible, large, multi-touch computer monitors should be used for robotics programming, such monitors will allow more students to be directly involved in programming and programming discussions. These recommendations improve robotics instruction for middle school aged children and support girls’ learning in computer science.
